title: 114_hr2332
content: The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under which the Secretary of Transportation can make grants to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" creates a grant program for infrastructure projects that can be used by State governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities. Grants can be used for highway or bridge projects that significantly impact metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects impacting metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States. Eligible projects include highway or bridge projects under title 23, US Code, and public transportation projects under chapter 53, US Code. The grant program established by the "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" covers infrastructure projects such as road system reconstruction, bridge replacements, seismic retrofit projects, road realignments, public transportation projects, and passenger or freight rail transportation projects. The grant program covers various infrastructure projects, including road system reconstruction, bridge replacements, seismic retrofit projects, road realignments, public transportation projects, passenger or freight rail transportation projects, port infrastructure investments, aviation infrastructure projects, and water infrastructure projects. The grant program covers infrastructure projects such as road reconstruction, bridge replacements, seismic retrofit projects, public transportation, rail projects, port infrastructure, aviation projects, and water projects. Coordination is required for water infrastructure projects with the EPA and Army. Applications and criteria for grant awards are specified. The Secretary must coordinate grants for water infrastructure projects with the EPA and Army. Eligible entities must submit applications for grant awards as determined by the Secretary. Entities eligible for grants must submit applications to the Secretary, who will determine the criteria for awarding grants on a competitive basis within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will issue regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment to specify criteria for competitive grant awards, including financial commitments for proposed projects. The Secretary will establish criteria for competitive grant awards, including financial commitments for proposed projects. Financial commitments must be from non-Federal sources, with a maximum Federal share of 100% of project costs. The Secretary will ensure that grants are distributed equitably, address urban and rural needs, and promote veteran training and employment. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 100%. The Secretary will ensure equitable distribution of grants, address urban and rural needs, promote veteran training and employment, and prioritize small businesses in grant utilization. The grants provided to veterans prioritize small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals and comply with Title 40 requirements. The grants prioritize small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals and must comply with Title 40 requirements, including Buy America provisions for using American-made iron, steel, and manufactured goods. The funds for a project under this Act must only be used if all iron, steel, and manufactured goods are made in the United States, with exceptions for cases where it is not feasible or in the public interest. Exceptions to the requirement for using American-made iron, steel, and manufactured goods include cases where it is not in the public interest, not produced in sufficient quantities or quality in the US, or if their inclusion increases project costs by more than 25 percent. Exceptions to the Buy American requirement include cases where using American-made products would increase project costs by over 25%. If a waiver is deemed necessary, a detailed justification must be published in the Federal Register. This waiver process must align with US international agreements. When a waiver is needed for the Buy American requirement, a detailed justification must be published in the Federal Register. This process must align with US international agreements and ensure transparency and accountability in grant utilization. The Secretary must ensure grants are used efficiently, provide grant information on a Department of Transportation website, and report to Congress annually on grants made under the program. The Secretary must provide grant information on a Department of Transportation website and report to Congress annually on grants made under the program, coordinating with relevant Federal departments for streamlined environmental reviews. The Secretary is required to coordinate with relevant Federal departments to ensure environmental reviews are conducted efficiently for projects funded by grants. $985 billion is authorized for grants under the program from 2016 to 2020. Authorization of Appropriations: $985 billion is authorized for grants under the program from 2016 to 2020, with 85% of the funds allocated for specific project types. From 2016 to 2020, $985 billion is authorized for grants, with 85% allocated for specific project types, including (A), (B), or (C) projects receiving 85%, (D) projects receiving 2%, (E) projects receiving 4%, and 9% for other projects. 2% of the funds are allocated for projects under subparagraph (D) of subsection (c)(1), 4% for projects under subparagraph (E), and 9% for projects under subparagraph (F). The Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The initiative allows the issuance of bonds by the Treasury, not exceeding $300 billion, with specific characteristics determined by the Treasury Secretary. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue bonds not exceeding $300 billion under specific terms. The proceeds will be given to the Secretary of Transportation for the program established under this Act. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
